titleStmt.title: Despatch from J. Milton Turner to John L. Cadwalader, May 25, 1876

bibl.title: Despatch from J. Milton Turner to John L. Cadwalader
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States
Republic of Liberia

J Milton Turner
to the
Department of State
Washington U.S.A.
Transmitting copy of protest of Messrs Pettengill and Everett, Agents for Messrs Mansfield and Roberts of Boston.

No. 1 Copy of note from Messrs Pettengill and Everett.
No. 2. Copy of protest of Messrs Pettengill and Everett.
No. 3. Reply of Mr Turner to Messrs Pettengill and Everett

St Louis, State of Missouri
November 29th, 1876

I have the honor to transmit herewith for the information of the Department, marked inclosure No. 1. a copy of a note which was received by me at this place, today, conveying to me from Messrs Pettengill and Everett, agents at Salt Pond, West Coast of Africa, for Messrs Mansfield and Roberts of Boston Massachusetts, the protest of the said Pettengill and Everett against a decision rendered by certain courts of Her Majesty's colonial settlements of Sera and the Gold Coast, West Africa. It appears that the protest refered to, was originally addressed to the Legation at Monrovia, and sent thence under date of September 23, through mistake, with my personal letters to my address at this place. A copy of the protest of Messrs Pettengill and Everett, as well as a copy of my reply to their note to me from accompaniments with
Honorable
John L. Cadawalder
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington
with this despatch, and are marked inclosure No. 2. and inclosure No. 3., respectively

I have the honor to be
Sir:
With high consideration and esteem,
Your obedient servant
J. Milton Turner
The Boston firm refered to written are Messrs Roberts and Mansfield; and not Mansfield and Roberts as stated in tthe body of this despatch.

Very respectfully
Your obedient servant
J Milton Turner

Salt Pond West Coast Africa
4th July 1876

To the Honorable
U.S. Minister at Liberia

We the undersigned American citizens doing business in the Gold Coast West Coast Africa as Agents for Messrs Roberts and Mansfield of Boston, there being no U.S. Counsil or Commercial Agent on the Coast and sharing no where means of getting redress humbly beg to submit to you notice a copy
